editionStmt.funder: Conversion of the printed catalogue to TEI funded by the Warden and Fellows of Merton College .

msDesc.head: AL-GAZALI, ALBERTUS MAGNUS; S. XIV med.

msItem.note: f. irv blank. On the verso can be seen the very faint remains of a table of contents, apparently washed off.

msItem.author: ALGAZEL
msItem.title: Logic
msItem.incipit: Quod autem preponi debet hoc est quod scienciarum quamuis sint multi rami
msItem.explicit: ostendere et facere intelligi de logica.

msItem.author: ALGAZEL
msItem.title: Physics
msItem.incipit: Incipit phisica Algazelis in qua continentur
Iam diximus quod ea que sunt diuiduntur in substantia et accidens
msItem.explicit: hic igitur est quod nos uolumus inducere de scientiis philosophorum, logicis, diuinis et naturalibus.
msItem.note: ed. J. T. Muckle, Algazel’s Metaphysics (Toronto, 1933), pp. 130–97.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, Physica
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber phisicorum siue auditus phisici
msItem.incipit: Intencio nostra in philosophia naturali est satisfacere pro nostra possibilitate fratribus ordinis nostri
msItem.finalRubric: uel reprehendant uel dimittant secundum quod placuerit eis. S. S. Explicit viii. liber phisicorum secundum fratrem Albertum et totus per consequens.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Caelo et Mundo
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber primus de celo et mundo
msItem.incipit: De celo et mundo in hoc secundo libro naturarum nostrarum loqui cupientes
msItem.explicit: in eo que fuerunt nostre intencionis in hac materia.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit de celo et mundo. Deo gracias.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Natura Loci
msItem.incipit: De natura locorum que prouenit ex habitudine loci ad celum
msItem.explicit: (Tr. 3 c. 8 [ed. p. 43 line 41]) que habent ab oriente Numidiam.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Causis Proprietatum Elementorum
msItem.incipit: Incipit liber de causis proprietatum elementorum
Quoniam autem iam nos compleuimus ea communiter que de natura et distinctione locorum dicenda sunt
msItem.explicit: ut de generacione et corrupcione generabilium et corruptibilium Deo auxiliante desteramus [pro disseramus].

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Generatione et Corruptione
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de generacione et corrupcione
msItem.incipit: Cum due sint consideraciones de mobili simplici
msItem.explicit: in iii. et iv. de celo et mundo dicta sunt.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de generatione et corruptione. Qui scripsit carmen sit benedictus. Amen

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Anima
msItem.incipit: Omnibus que de corpore mobili et de mobili secundum locum dicenda erant expeditis
msItem.explicit: quod in se ipsa consideratur determinata sufficiant.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de anima secundum fratrum Albertum.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Nutrimento et Nutrito
msItem.incipit: De anima secundum seipsam in precedenti libro dictum est
msItem.explicit: secundum Perypaticos dicta sunt a nobis.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de nutrimento et nutrito. Iohannes Wyliot.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Sensu et Sensato
msItem.incipit: Qoniam autem de anima secundum ipsam considerata iam in libro de anima determinatum est
msItem.explicit: cum hiis que in libro de anima sunt considerata.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Memoria et Reminiscentia
msItem.incipit: Reliquorum autem primum considerandum est de memoria
msItem.explicit: propter quas causas contingit utrumque ipsorum.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Intellectu et Intelligibili
msItem.incipit: Sicut a principio istius operis diximus
msItem.explicit: philosophie agens inquisicione

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Somno et Vigilia
msItem.incipit: Incipit liber primus de somno et uigilia
Sompnus et uigilia non sunt nisi passiones animalis
msItem.explicit: quod intendimus a principio querere de hac materia.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Spiritu et Respiratione
msItem.incipit: Liber primus de spiritu et respiratione
Multa sunt animalia que quidem secundum locum mouentur
msItem.explicit: hec igitur de differentiis eorum dicta sunt.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de inspiracione et respiracione.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Motibus Animalium
msItem.incipit: Tempus et ordo expostulant quod de animalium motibus hic disseramus
msItem.explicit: sic igitur de motibus animalium determinatum sit a nobis.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Morte et Vita
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de morte et uita
msItem.incipit: Probatum est in fine primi celi et mundi
msItem.explicit: ex multitudine accidencium que sunt infinita hec de causa uite breuioris et longioris dicta sufficiant.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit de morte et uita et de causa breuioris uite et longioris

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, De Iuuentute et Senectute
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de etate siue de iuuentute et senectute
msItem.incipit: Iam explerumus omnia que de passionibus et operibus anime uidebantur esse dicenda
msItem.explicit: que nos determinauimus in quarto phisicorum.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber de iuuentute et senectute.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Natura et Origine Animae
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber de natura et origine anime
msItem.incipit: De anima quidem secundum quod est perfectio corporis
msItem.explicit: et statu anime incorruptione et opere tantum dictum est a nobis. Explicit ...

msItem.author: Ps.-ARISTOTLE
msItem.title: Liber de Causis
msItem.incipit: Omnis causa primaria plus influit
Cum ergo remouet causa secunda
msItem.explicit: non adquisitum sicut ostendimus.
msItem.note: Ed. A. Pattin in Tijdschrift voor Filosofie 28 (1966), 90–203, text from 134; eTK 0996A (text), 335 (‘commentary’). The ‘commentary’, variously ascribed in the MSS, is in fact a set of demonstrations added by the compiler of the main text; Pattin integrates the two.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on ARISTOTLE, Meteora
msItem.incipit: In sciencia naturali corpus mobile subiectum est
msItem.explicit: ideo sequens sciencia in tria diuidetur.
msItem.note: AMO (Geyer) 6/1 (not using this copy); Glorieux, Théol. 6af; Fauser 16, 24.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: De Mineralibus
msItem.rubric: Incipit liber primus mineralium qui est de lapidibus
msItem.incipit: De mixtione et coagulacione similiter autem et congelacione
msItem.explicit: de facili poterunt cognosci.

msItem.author: ALBERTUS MAGNUS
msItem.title: Commentary on Ps.-ARISTOTLE, De Vegetabilibus et Plantis
msItem.incipit: Vniuersalibus principiis uiuorum omnium et eorum operibus executis
msItem.explicit: et sufficienter poterant agnosci.
msItem.note: AMO (Borgnet) 10. 1–305; Glorieux, Théol. 6bb; Lohr, p. 343; Fauser 28.

supportDesc.extent:
362 leaves (i + 360, incl. 229A) 375 265
300–10 180–95
The edges retrimmed and spattered with red. Foliated early on in arabic numerals, 1 (mod. 5)-60 (mod. 64), 61 (mod. 75)-101, 103–167, 173–354 (360), the replacement quire 6 not then being present; the two breaks in the sequence are due to the subsequent loss of blank leaves.
supportDesc.collation: A singleton, A4, 1–512 / 610 / 712, 86, 912, 1012(12 canc.), 11–1512, 1610(6–10 canc.), 17–2712, 2814, 29–3012, 3112(10–12 canc.); catchwords, framed in red, often cropped. Fols. 241 and 250 were bound in the reverse position after the foliation, but early enough for the rubricator to warn of it.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled with fine pencil in 2 cols of 79–89 lines (61 quire 6).

handDesc.handNote: Written in several English hands, mostly gothic rotunda bookhands, sometimes approaching textualis, sometimes anglicana. Fols. 5–64v, 93–115, 154–228 at least are in the hand of John Wylyot, who signs on f. 228. He may be responsible for more, as even on these leaves his hand varies in size and formality: Parkes, English Cursive Bookhands, pl. 16(ii). Quire 6 (fols. 65–74v), replacing a lost or damaged quire, is written in an expert anglicana, s. xv2.

decoDesc.decoNote: Spasmodic, probably Oxford work; many unfilled spaces for coloured initials and rubrics. Red and blue flourished initials; red or blue initials flourished in the other colour; plain red initials and paraphs. Occasional marginal sketches in pen and ink: on 154v a drollery blows a large trumpet with gonfanon; a ?jester, tinted with colours, at the foot of f. 155; on 160v a goat eats leaves from an oak tree.

binding.p: Standard Merton s. xvii, sewn on six bands; formerly chained from the usual position. f. i, formerly the pastedown in an earlier binding, has a rust mark at the foot perhaps from a chain-staple. Rust marks on the early leaves suggest that a previous binding had a central foredge strap replaced by two, and one each at head and tail.

history.provenance: Made mainly by and presumably for John Wyliot (BRUO 2119), who doubtless gave or left it to the College. He was fellow of Merton in 1338, no longer in 1347–8, d. by Dec. 1383. Perhaps to be identified with the record of payment ‘in luicione libri Wylioti et est Albertus super naturali philosophia’ (Appendix B, no. 62, dated 1379).

On fols. i and 5 is the James no. ‘99’, s. xvii in. Inside the front board is a sheet of paper with table of contents, s. xvii, and ‘Q. 2. 1. Art:’, canc. and replaced with ‘O. 2. 1 (CCLXXXV)’ in red; the College bookplate.

source.bibl: R. M. Thomson, A descriptive catalogue of the medieval manuscripts of Merton College, Oxford (Cambridge: D. S. Brewer), 2009.

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact Merton College Library.

listBibl.bibl: Coxe, pp. 113–14; Powicke, no. 389; M.-Th. d’Alverny, ‘Avicenna latinus V’, AHDLMA 32 (1965), 257–302, at pp. 288–9.
